Award.AwardTitle: EAPS: When and Where Do Objects Become Scenes

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a fraction of a second—from a single glance--people can comprehend real-world scenes, not just as an inventory list of the individual objects but in the coding of the structure specified by the relations among them. The typical real-world visual experience is one where interacting objects can provide contextual cues for object recognition, e.g., there is a sharp contrast in meaning when a pitcher is positioned to pour water towards a cup than away from it despite there being two identical objects in both scenarios. These object interactions (e.g., a hand holding a pen) have shown to facilitate the recognition of the individual objects than compared to objects presented side-by-side (e.g., a hand next to a pen). Where in the brain are these inter-object relations registered? 

To test which region gives rise to this behavioral efficiency of the coding of object interactions (i.e., the scene facilitation effect), we flashed pictures of pairs of objects either positioned to interact with each other or not. Participants’ task was to press a button if a label, presented as a word displayed after the pictures, matched one of the two objects presented. Previously we have shown that the lateral occipital complex (LOC), the first area on the lower back of the brain where intact shapes are preferred over scrambled pictures, shows greater activity to pairs of objects shown as interacting than not interacting. This makes LOC a likely candidate for the origin of the scene facilitation effect. However, LOC could have received modulatory input from the intraparietal sulcus (IPS), which is engaged in visual attention. To the extent that the interacting pairs attracted more attention than the side-by-side objects, it is possible that IPS was involved.

While participants performed the target-matching task, either LOC or IPS activity was temporarily and safely disrupted by applying transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). When TMS was applied to IPS, there was no effect on the scene facilitation effect. Subjects were just as more accurate in the matching task when object pairs were shown as interacting than not interacting, as if no brain region was disrupted. However, when LOC activity was disrupted, the scene facilitation effect was completely abolished, suggesting that LOC plays a critical role in the processing of relations between multiple objects. The coding of inter-object relations is thus not relegated to an attentional cortical region, such as IPS, but processed at the same cortical locus and possibly simultaneous with the processing of object shape.
